Good man!
All sentient beings, from beginningless time, due to various kinds of affection and lust, have cyclic existence.

In all worlds, all kinds of beings, born from eggs, wombs, moisture, or spontaneously, all due to sexual desire establish their life-force. One should know that cyclic existence takes love as its root.
Due to various desires, it aids in giving rise to the nature of love. Therefore, it can cause the continuity of birth and death.
Desire arises from love, and life is due to desire. Sentient beings love life and still rely on the basis of desire.
Love and desire are the cause, and loving life is the result.

Due to the various agreeable and disagreeable objects of desire, the mind that loves objects gives rise to hatred and jealousy. One creates various karmas. Therefore, one is reborn in the hells and hungry ghost realms.
Knowing that desire is to be detested, one detests the path of karmic action. Abandoning evil and delighting in goodness, one is reborn as a god or human.

Moreover, knowing that all craving is to be abhorred, one abandons craving and delights in giving, but this only nourishes the roots of craving and leads to the manifestation of the superior wholesome fruits of conditioned existence, all of which are due to cyclic existence, and thus one does not accomplish the holy path.
Therefore, sentient beings who wish to escape birth and death and avoid all cyclic existence should first sever craving and eliminate the thirst for love.
Good sons!
The transformations and manifestations of bodhisattvas in the world are not based on love, but only with compassion to make them abandon love, and use various cravings to enter birth and death.

If all sentient beings in the degenerate age are able to abandon all desires, eliminate hatred and love, forever cut off cyclic existence, diligently seek the realm of perfect enlightenment, and attain pure enlightenment in their pure minds,
Good sons!
All sentient beings, due to their original craving, manifest the five natures unequally, based on two kinds of obstacles, which appear in varying degrees.
What are the two obstacles?
First, the principle obstacle obstructs correct knowledge and insight; second, the phenomenal obstacle continues the cycle of birth and death.
What are the five natures?
Good sons!
If these two obstacles have not yet been eliminated, one is not yet a Buddha.

If sentient beings forever abandon craving and first eliminate the phenomenal obstacle but have not yet eliminated the principle obstacle, they can only awaken to and enter the stage of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and are not yet able to manifestly abide in the bodhisattva stage.
Good sons!

If all sentient beings in the degenerate age wish to sail the great ocean of the TathÄgata's perfect enlightenment, they should first make vows and diligently eliminate the two obstacles. Once the two obstacles have been subdued, they can awaken to and enter the bodhisattva stage;
If the phenomenal and principle obstacles have been permanently eliminated, they will enter the TathÄgata's subtle perfect enlightenment and fulfill perfect enlightenment and great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!

All sentient beings equally realize perfect enlightenment. Encountering a good and virtuous friend, relying on the practices of the ground of causes that they cultivate, at that time there are sudden and gradual approaches to cultivation;
If they encounter the unsurpassed bodhi and the correct path of practice, whether their faculties are sharp or dull, they will all attain Buddhahood.

If sentient beings, although seeking good friends, encounter those with wrong views and have not attained right understanding, they are then called those of the nature of non-Buddhists. This is the fault of the wrong teachers, not the fault of the sentient beings.
These are called the five natures of sentient beings.
Good sons!

Bodhisattvas, with only great compassion and skillful means, enter the various worlds to enlighten those who are not yet awakened, and even manifest various appearances and go against and follow circumstances, engaging in the same activities as them to transform and cause them to attain Buddhahood. All of this relies on the power of pure vows from the beginningless past.
If all sentient beings in the degenerate age arouse an exalted mind towards the great perfect enlightenment, they should give rise to the pure great vows of bodhisattvas and say these words:
'I now abide in the perfect enlightenment of the Buddha, seek good and virtuous friends, and do not associate with non-Buddhists or the two vehicles.'

Relying on the vow to cultivate, gradually severing the various hindrances, when the hindrances are exhausted and the vow is fulfilled, one then ascends to the pure Dharma palace of liberation and realizes the wondrous adornment realm of great perfect enlightenment.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Maitreya, you should know that all sentient beings,
Not attaining great liberation, are all due to craving and desire,
Falling into birth and death.
As well as craving, anger, and delusion, not due to distinctions in nature,
All can attain Buddhahood.
Seeking a teacher to attain right understanding, in accordance with the vow of enlightenment,
Relying on great nirvana.
The bodhisattvas of the ten directions all, with the vow of great compassion, manifest entering birth and death.
The present practitioners, as well as sentient beings in the final age,
Diligent in severing all attachments and views, will then return to great perfect enlightenment.

Then, the Bodhisattva Pure Wisdom rose from his seat in the great assembly, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
Greatly compassionate World-Honored One!

For our sake, you have extensively explained such inconceivable matters, which we have never seen before and never heard before. We now, having received the Buddha's kind guidance, are at ease in body and mind and have gained great benefit. We only wish that, for the sake of all the Dharma assemblies that have come, you would once again proclaim the perfect enlightened nature of the Dharma King, and how the realization and attainment of all sentient beings, bodhisattvas, and the World-Honored TathÄgatas differ.
May the sentient beings of the Dharma-ending age, upon hearing this sacred teaching, be able to understand it in accordance with it and gradually enter it.
Having said this, he prostrated fully on the ground, making this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the Bodhisattva Pure Wisdom:ğŸ”½Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Good man!
You are now able to request the TathÄgata to explain the gradual distinctions for the bodhisattvas and sentient beings of the degenerate age.
You should listen attentively!
I will now explain for you.
At that time, the bodhisattva Pure Wisdom respectfully accepted the teaching with joy, and the great assembly listened in silence.
Good sons!

The intrinsic nature of perfect enlightenment is not a nature, yet within nature there is the arising of all natures. There is no grasping and no realization. In the true reality there are truly no bodhisattvas or sentient beings.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattvas and sentient beings are all illusory transformations. Because illusory transformations cease, there is no one who grasps or realizes.
It is just like the eye faculty not being able to see the eye itself. The nature is inherently equal.

There is no one who is equal. Sentient beings are deluded and inverted, and are unable to eliminate all illusory transformations. Within the deluded effort to eliminate or not eliminate, distinctions are then revealed.
If one attains the TathÄgata's quiescence and accord with cessation, there is truly no quiescence or one who attains quiescence.
Good sons!

All sentient beings, from beginningless time until now, due to the false imagination of self and attachment to self, have never known the arising and ceasing of each moment of thought, and thus give rise to aversion and attachment, indulging in the five desires.

If they encounter a good friend who teaches them to open up and awaken to the pure and perfect nature of enlightenment, and to illuminate the arising and ceasing, they will then know that this life's nature is itself weary and anxious.

If there are people who permanently sever weariness and anxiety and attain the purity of the Dharma realm, then that pure understanding becomes an obstruction to themselves, and thus they are not free in perfect enlightenment.
This is called ordinary beings following the nature of enlightenment.
Good sons!

All bodhisattvas take views as obstructions. Although they sever the obstruction of views, they still abide in the realization of awareness. The obstruction of awareness becomes an obstruction, and they are not free.
This is called bodhisattvas who have not yet entered the grounds following the nature of enlightenment.
Good sons!

Illumination and cognition are both called obstacles. Therefore, bodhisattvas always abide in non-abiding awareness. Illumination and the illuminator simultaneously cease. It is like a person who cuts off their own head. Since the head is already cut off, there is no one who can cut it off;
Then, with an obstructed mind, one extinguishes all obstructions. When obstructions are already extinguished, there is no one who extinguishes obstructions.
The teachings of the sutras are like pointing to the moon. If one sees the moon, one knows that the pointing is ultimately not the moon;
The various teachings of all tathagatas that reveal bodhisattvas are also like this.
This is called the bodhisattvas who have entered the grounds and accord with the nature of enlightenment.
Good sons!

All obstacles are the ultimate enlightenment. Whether mindful or not, there is no distinction in liberation. Whether cultivating or destroying the Dharma, both are called nirvana. Wisdom and foolishness are all prajÃ±a. The accomplished dharmas of bodhisattvas and non-Buddhists are the same as bodhi. Ignorance and true suchness have no different realms. All precepts, concentration, wisdom, desire, anger, and delusion are all brahmacarya. Sentient beings and lands are the same in their inherent nature. Hells and heavenly palaces are all pure lands. Those with and without the nature equally attain Buddhahood.
All afflictions are ultimately liberated. The wisdom of the ocean of the Dharma realm illuminates all phenomena as if they were empty space.
This is called the TathÄgata's conformity with the nature of enlightenment.
Good sons!

Only bodhisattvas and sentient beings in the final age, at all times, do not give rise to false thoughts, and also do not extinguish false thoughts. Abiding in the realm of false thoughts, they do not apply understanding. In the absence of understanding, they do not discern the truth.
Those sentient beings who hear this teaching, believe and understand it, accept and uphold it without giving rise to fear,
are said to be in accord with the nature of enlightenment.
Good sons!
You should know!
Such sentient beings have already made offerings to koá¹­is of nayutas of sentient beings equal to the sands of the Ganges River, to buddhas and great bodhisattvas, and planted roots of virtue;
The Buddha says that such people are called those who have accomplished omniscience.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Pure Wisdom, you should know, the perfect nature of enlightenment,
Is without grasping and without realization, without bodhisattvas and sentient beings.
When one is enlightened and not yet enlightened, there are gradual distinctions,
Sentient beings are obstructed by understanding, bodhisattvas have not yet left behind enlightenment.
Entering the grounds, eternally quiescent and extinguished, not abiding in any characteristics,
Great enlightenment is completely perfect, called thoroughly in accord.
Sentient beings in the degenerate age, whose minds do not give rise to delusion,
The Buddha says such people are bodhisattvas in the present world.
Making offerings to buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, their merit already complete,
Although there are many skillful means, they are all called the wisdom of accord.

Then the bodhisattva Powerful and Independent, in the great assembly, immediately rose from his seat, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
Greatly compassionate World-Honored One!

You have extensively distinguished for us in this way the nature of accord with enlightenment, enabling the bodhisattvas to illuminate the enlightened mind by receiving the Buddha's perfect sound, and to attain good benefits without relying on cultivation and practice.
World-Honored One!

It is like a great city with four gates outside, those who come from the four directions do not take only one road, and all bodhisattvas adorn the Buddha's country and attain enlightenment, not by a single skillful means.
I only wish that the World-Honored One!
Please extensively explain for us all the gradual methods and the general types of practitioners,
So that the bodhisattvas in this assembly and sentient beings of the degenerate age who seek the Great Vehicle can quickly attain enlightenment and play in the TathÄgata's ocean of great quiescence.
Having said this, he prostrated fully on the ground, making this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the Bodhisattva Powerful and Independent:
Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Good man!
You are now able to ask the TathÄgata about such skillful means for the sake of the bodhisattvas and sentient beings of the degenerate age.
Listen attentively now!
I will explain it for you.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Powerful and Independent accepted the teaching with joy, and the great assembly listened in silence.
Good man!

The unsurpassed wondrous enlightenment pervades the ten directions and gives rise to the TathÄgatas. It is of the same essence as all dharmas and is fundamentally non-dual in the practice of cultivation.
The methods of following it are innumerable, but they can be summarized as three types according to their differences in nature.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas awaken to pure perfect enlightenment and use their pure enlightened mind to take stillness as practice,

by clarifying all thoughts, the agitated consciousness is awakened, and the wisdom of stillness arises, causing the guest-dust of body and mind to be forever extinguished from this point on. They are then able to internally give rise to tranquil ease.
Because of tranquility, the minds of the tathÄgatas in the ten directions manifest within it, like images in a mirror.
This method is called Å›amatha.
Good sons!

If bodhisattvas awaken to pure perfect enlightenment and use their pure enlightened mind to know the nature of the mind of enlightenment and the faculties and objects are all due to illusory transformations, they then give rise to various illusions to eliminate the illusion-maker, transforming various illusions to open the illusory assembly;
by giving rise to illusions, they are then able to internally give rise to great compassion and ease. All bodhisattvas give rise to practices from this point on, gradually increasing and progressing.
Because the observer of illusions is not the same as the illusions, and because all observations that are the same as illusions are themselves illusions, illusory appearances are forever abandoned.
This is the wondrous practice perfected by these bodhisattvas, like a plant growing in the earth.
This skillful means is called samÄpatti.
Good sons!

If bodhisattvas awaken to pure perfect enlightenment, with their pure enlightened mind they do not grasp at illusory transformations or various tranquil appearances, and clearly understand that body and mind are all obstructions;

With unobstructed enlightened understanding, they do not rely on any obstructions, and forever transcend the realm of obstruction and non-obstruction, as well as the enjoyment of the world and body and mind. The characteristics remain in the realm of dust;

Like the sound of a bell in a container coming out from the outside, afflictions and nirvÄá¹‡a do not obstruct each other. They are then able to inwardly give rise to the blissful ease of quiescence, the wondrous enlightenment that accords with the realm of quiescence, which is beyond the reach of one's own and others' body and mind. The life of sentient beings is all floating thoughts.
This skillful means is called dhyÄna.
Good sons!
These three Dharma gates are all perfect enlightenment.

Approaching and following the Tathagatas of the ten directions, based on this they attain Buddhahood. The various skillful means of the Bodhisattvas of the ten directions, all the same and different, are all based on these three kinds of activities. If one attains perfect realization, one will accomplish perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

Suppose someone cultivates the holy path, teaching and transforming hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of Arhats and Pratyekabuddha fruits, it is not as good as someone hearing this unobstructed Dharma gate of perfect enlightenment, for a single moment following and cultivating it.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Virtuous One, you should know that the mind of supreme great enlightenment,
The original state has no two characteristics, following the various skillful means,
Their number is then immeasurable.
There are then three kinds: The tranquil Å›amatha,
Like a mirror reflecting various images;
Like an illusory samÄdhi, like seedlings gradually growing;
DhyÄna is only quiescent extinction, like a bell in a container.
All of this is in accordance with enlightenment, the tathÄgatas of the ten directions,
And the great bodhisattvas, because of this they attain enlightenment.
Because the three matters are perfectly realized, it is called ultimate nirvÄá¹‡a.

Then Bodhisattva Bianzhong rose from his seat in the great assembly, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
Greatly compassionate World-Honored One!
Such a Dharma door is extremely rare!
World-Honored One!
How many practices are there for all bodhisattvas in the gate of perfect enlightenment?
Please explain expediently for the great assembly and sentient beings of the degenerate age, enabling them to awaken to the true nature.
Having said this, he prostrated fully on the ground, making this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Bodhisattva Bianzhong:
Excellent! Excellent!
Good man!
You are able to ask the TathÄgata on behalf of the great assembly and sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age about the practice of this kind.
Listen attentively now!
I will explain it for you.
At that time, Bodhisattva Bian Zhong said, Excellent! and joyfully accepted the teaching, while the great assembly listened in silence.
Good man!

All TathÄgatas' perfect enlightenment is pure and originally has no cultivation or cultivator. All Bodhisattvas and sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age rely on the illusory power of non-enlightenment to cultivate. At that time, there are twenty-five kinds of pure samÄdhi wheels:
If Bodhisattvas only attain utmost stillness, by the power of stillness they permanently sever afflictions and ultimately accomplish [nirvÄá¹‡a], without rising from their seats they enter nirvÄá¹‡a;
this Bodhisattva is called one who single-mindedly cultivates Å›amatha.

If bodhisattvas only observe the illusory, and through the Buddha's power transform and create various functions in the world, and fully practice the pure and wondrous practices of bodhisattvas, without losing the silent mind and various tranquil wisdoms in dharani, these bodhisattvas are called those who single-mindedly cultivate samadhi.
If bodhisattvas only extinguish all illusions, do not grasp functions, and single-mindedly sever afflictions, when the afflictions are completely severed they will realize the true nature;
these bodhisattvas are called those who single-mindedly cultivate dhyana.
If bodhisattvas first attain utmost stillness, and with the mind of tranquil wisdom illuminate all illusions, and then give rise to bodhisattva practices within this,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate shamatha and later cultivate samapatti.
If bodhisattvas, due to tranquil wisdom, realize the nature of utmost stillness, and then sever afflictions and permanently escape from birth and death;
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate shamatha and later cultivate dhyana.
If bodhisattvas, with the wisdom of tranquility, further manifest illusory powers and various transformations to liberate sentient beings, and later sever afflictions and enter tranquility,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate Å›amatha, next cultivate samÄdhi, and finally cultivate dhyÄna.
If bodhisattvas, with the power of utmost tranquility, sever afflictions and later give rise to the pure and wondrous practices of bodhisattvas to liberate sentient beings,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate Å›amatha, next cultivate dhyÄna, and finally cultivate samÄdhi.
If bodhisattvas, with the power of utmost tranquility, sever afflictions in the mind and further liberate sentient beings and establish the world,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate Å›amatha and cultivate both samÄdhi and dhyÄna equally.
If bodhisattvas, with the power of utmost tranquility, assist in giving rise to transformations and later sever afflictions,
these bodhisattvas are called those who cultivate Å›amatha and samÄdhi equally and finally cultivate dhyÄna.
If the bodhisattvas use the power of utmost stillness to assist in quiescent extinction, and then give rise to activity and transform the realm,
these bodhisattvas are called those who practice Å›amatha and dhyÄna equally, and then practice samÄdhi afterwards.
If the bodhisattvas use the power of transformation to accord with various [phenomena] and attain utmost stillness,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first practice samÄdhi, and then practice Å›amatha.
If the bodhisattvas use the power of transformation and various realms to attain quiescent extinction,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first practice samÄdhi, and then practice dhyÄna.
If the bodhisattvas use the power of transformation to perform buddha-works, abide in stillness, and sever afflictions,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first practice samÄdhi, then practice Å›amatha in the middle, and then practice dhyÄna afterwards.
If the bodhisattvas, by the power of transformation and unobstructed function, cut off afflictions and abide in tranquility,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate samÄdhi, then cultivate dhyÄna, and finally cultivate Å›amatha.
If the bodhisattvas, by the power of transformation and skillful function, accord with both tranquility and cessation,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate samÄdhi and cultivate Å›amatha and dhyÄna equally.
If the bodhisattvas, by the power of transformation, arouse various functions to support tranquility and later cut off afflictions,
these bodhisattvas are called those who cultivate samÄdhi and Å›amatha equally and finally cultivate dhyÄna.
If the bodhisattvas, by the power of transformation, support cessation and later abide in pure, effortless concentration,
these bodhisattvas are called those who cultivate samÄdhi and dhyÄna equally and finally cultivate Å›amatha.
If bodhisattvas use the power of quiescence to give rise to utmost tranquility and abide in purity,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate dhyÄna and later cultivate Å›amatha.
If bodhisattvas use the power of quiescence to give rise to function and in all realms the function of quiescence accords with conditions,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate dhyÄna and later cultivate samÄdhi.
If bodhisattvas use the power of quiescence to give rise to various natures, abide in meditative concentration, and give rise to transformations,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate dhyÄna, next cultivate Å›amatha, and later cultivate samÄdhi.
If bodhisattvas use the power of quiescence to give rise to function with no inherent nature of action, and the pure realm returns to meditative concentration,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate dhyÄna, next cultivate samÄdhi, and later cultivate Å›amatha.
If bodhisattvas, with the power of quiescence and various purities, abide in meditation and give rise to transformations,
these bodhisattvas are called those who first cultivate Å›amatha, and then cultivate vipaÅ›yanÄ and samÄdhi equally.
If bodhisattvas, with the power of quiescence, assist in ultimate stillness and give rise to transformations,
these bodhisattvas are called those who cultivate Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ equally, and then cultivate samÄdhi.
If bodhisattvas, with the power of quiescence, assist in transformations and give rise to ultimate stillness, clear and bright wisdom of the realm,
these bodhisattvas are called those who cultivate Å›amatha and samÄdhi equally, and then cultivate vipaÅ›yanÄ.
If bodhisattvas, with perfect enlightenment wisdom, perfectly merge with everything, and in all natures and characteristics are not apart from the nature of enlightenment,
these bodhisattvas are called those who perfectly cultivate the three kinds of natures and are pure and in accord with [the nature of enlightenment].
Good sons!
These are called the twenty-five samÄdhi gates of the bodhisattvas. All bodhisattvas practice in this way.
If bodhisattvas and sentient beings of the Dharma-ending age rely on these samÄdhi gates, they should maintain pure conduct, contemplate in stillness, seek compassion and repent, for three weeks.
In each of the twenty-five samÄdhi gates, place a mark. With utmost sincerity, seek compassion and randomly select one.
Based on the selected one, reveal the teaching and then know whether it is sudden or gradual. If there is even a moment of doubt or regret, it will not be accomplished.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, you should know that all bodhisattvas'
Unimpeded and pure wisdom all arises from dhyÄna concentration.
Namely, Å›amatha, samÄdhi, and dhyÄna,
The three dharmas are practiced suddenly or gradually, there are twenty-five kinds.
The tathÄgatas of the ten directions, the practitioners of the three times,
There is none who does not attain enlightenment by relying on this Dharma,
Except for those who are suddenly enlightened, and those who do not follow the Dharma.
All bodhisattvas and sentient beings in the final age,
Should always uphold this wheel and diligently practice in accordance with it,
Relying on the Buddha's power of great compassion, they will soon realize nirvana.

Then the Bodhisattva Purifying All Karmic Hindrances rose from his seat in the great assembly, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
Greatly compassionate World-Honored One!

For our sake, you have extensively explained such inconceivable matters, the characteristics of the causal grounds of all tathÄgatas, enabling the great assembly to experience the unprecedented, to behold the Tamer's [Buddha's] diligent practice of the realms of the Ganges sands [of kalpas] as if in a single thought. We bodhisattvas deeply rejoice and comfort ourselves.
World-Honored One!
If this enlightened mind is originally pure by nature, why is it defiled, causing sentient beings to be confused and unable to enter?
I only wish that the TathÄgata will extensively open up the Dharma-nature for us, enabling the great assembly and sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age to have eyes for the future.
Having said this, he prostrated fully on the ground, making this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to Bodhisattva Purified of Karmic Hindrances:
Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Good man!
You are now able to ask the TathÄgata about such skillful means for the sake of the great assembly and sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age.
Listen attentively now!
I will explain it for you.
At that time, Bodhisattva Purified of Karmic Hindrances respectfully accepted the teaching with joy, and the great assembly listened in silence.
Good man!

All sentient beings, from beginningless time, have mistakenly clung to the existence of self, person, sentient being, and life, and taken the four inverted views as the true essence of self. Because of this, they give rise to the two realms of aversion and love.

Heavily clinging to the illusory body with illusory thoughts, the two illusions rely on each other to give rise to illusory karmic paths. Because of illusory karma, illusory saá¹ƒsÄra is seen. Those who are weary of saá¹ƒsÄra mistakenly see nirvÄá¹‡a.

Because of this, they are unable to enter pure enlightenment. Enlightenment does not obstruct those who are able to enter, but because of the entry of those who are able to enter, it is not enlightenment.
Therefore, whether the mind moves or rests, it all falls into delusion and confusion. Why is this?

Because of the fundamental ignorance that arises from beginningless time, which serves as one's master and controller. All sentient beings are born without the eyes of wisdom. The nature of body and mind is all ignorance, just as a person cannot cut off their own life.
Therefore, you should know!

Those who love me, I accord with; those who do not accord with me, I give rise to hatred and resentment. Because the mind of hatred and love nourishes ignorance, those who seek the Way in continuity will all not accomplish it.
Good sons!
What is the characteristic of self?
It refers to what is realized by the minds of all sentient beings.
Good sons!
It is like a person whose hundred skeletons are in harmony, suddenly forgetting their own body;
When the strings of the four limbs are loose, and the method of nourishing and protecting is wrong, if a needle or moxibustion is slightly applied, then they know there is a self.
Therefore, realizing and grasping it, then the body of self appears.
Good sons!
Their minds, up to realizing the TathÄgata, ultimately understanding and knowing pure nirvÄá¹‡a, are all the characteristic of self.
Good sons!
What is the characteristic of person?
It refers to what is realized and understood by the minds of all sentient beings.
Good sons!
Those who understand there is a self, do not again recognize a self. What is realized is not a self. Understanding is also like this.
After understanding, surpassing all realizations, are all the characteristics of a person.
Good man!

If one's mind even fully understands nirvÄá¹‡a and considers them all to be self, and if one's mind retains a little understanding and exhausts all the principles of realization, they are all called the characteristics of a person.
Good man!
What are the characteristics of sentient beings?
It refers to what sentient beings' minds themselves realize and experience but cannot reach.
Good man!
It is like a person who says like this:
'I am a sentient being.'
Then one knows that what that person says about sentient beings is neither self nor other.
Why is it not self?
If I am a sentient being, then it is not self.
Why is it not other?
Because I am a sentient being, it is not the self of others.
Good man!

It is just that all sentient beings who realize and awaken are considered self and person, but what is not reached by the characteristics of self and person, retaining something to be realized, is called the characteristics of sentient beings.
Good man!
What are the characteristics of life?
It refers to the pure illumination of the minds of sentient beings, which is realized through awakening. All karmic activities and wisdom cannot see it themselves, just like the life faculty.
Good sons!
If the mind illuminates and sees all awakenings, they are all defiled dust. Awakening and the object of awakening are not apart from dust.
Just as hot water melts ice, and there is no separate ice, knowing that the ice has melted, clinging to the self and being aware of the self is also like this.
Good sons!

Sentient beings in the degenerate age do not understand the four characteristics. Although they diligently cultivate the Way for many kalpas, it is only called conditioned, and they will never be able to accomplish the fruits of all sages. Therefore, it is called the degenerate age of the true Dharma.
Why is it so?
Because they take all selves to be nirvana, there is realization and there is awakening, which is called accomplishment.
It is like a person who takes a thief to be their child, and the wealth and treasures of their family will never be accomplished.
Why is it so?
Those who have self-love also love nirvana. Subduing the root of self-love is the characteristic of nirvana;
Those who hate me also hate birth and death, because they do not know that attachment is true birth and death. Separately hating birth and death is called not understanding liberation.
How can one know that the Dharma is not liberation?
Good man!
Those sentient beings in the final age who cultivate bodhi, using their slight realization as their own purity, are still unable to completely eliminate the root of the self-view.
If there are people who praise that Dharma, they will give rise to joy and immediately wish to save and liberate [them];
if there are people who slander what they have attained, they will give rise to anger and resentment.
Then know that the self-view is firmly grasped, hidden in the store consciousness, and plays with the faculties without interruption.
Good man!
Those who cultivate the path but do not eliminate the self-view are therefore unable to enter pure enlightenment.
Good man!
If one knows the emptiness of the self, there is no one who slanders the self. Because the self has not been eliminated, sentient beings and life are also like this.
Good man!
Sentient beings in the degenerate age speak of illness as the Dharma, and for this reason they are called pitiable ones;
Although they diligently strive, they increase their illnesses, and for this reason they are unable to enter pure enlightenment.
Good man!

Sentient beings in the degenerate age do not understand the four characteristics, and take the understanding and practice of the TathÄgata as their own practice, and in the end they will not accomplish anything.
Some sentient beings, not having attained, think they have attained, and not having realized, think they have realized, and when they see those who are superior, they give rise to jealousy;
Because those sentient beings have not yet eliminated their attachment to self, they are therefore unable to enter pure enlightenment.
Good man!
Sentient beings in the degenerate age hope to accomplish the Way, but do not seek understanding. They only increase their learning and enhance their views of self;

You should only be diligent in subduing afflictions and arouse great courage, to attain what has not been attained and eliminate what has not been eliminated. If greed, anger, love, arrogance, flattery, jealousy, and resentment do not arise in the face of objects, and self and others are all peacefully extinguished, the Buddha says that such a person will gradually accomplish [enlightenment].
Seeking good and wise advisors, one should not fall into wrong views. If one gives rise to hatred and love in one's seeking, one will not be able to enter the pure ocean of enlightenment.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Pure Karma, you should know that all sentient beings
Are all due to grasping at the self and love, wandering in delusion since beginningless [time].
If the four kinds of characteristics are not eliminated, one cannot attain enlightenment.
Love and hatred arise in the mind, flattery and deceit remain in all thoughts,
Therefore, there is much confusion and bewilderment, and one cannot enter the city of enlightenment.
If one can return to the enlightened realm, first remove greed, anger, and delusion,
If you do not harbor love and hatred in your mind, you can gradually accomplish [the Way].
Since my body originally does not exist, how can love and hatred arise?
If a person seeks a good friend, they will never fall into wrong views.
If you seek with a separate mind, you will not ultimately accomplish [your goal].

Then Bodhisattva Universal Awakening, in the great assembly, immediately rose from his seat, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
Greatly compassionate World-Honored One!
You have eloquently explained the illnesses of Chan meditation,
Causing the great assembly to attain what they have never had before, their minds and thoughts refreshed, and to attain great peace and comfort.
World-Honored One!

In the degenerate age, sentient beings are far removed from the Buddha, the sages and saints are in hiding, and deviant teachings flourish. What kind of people should sentient beings seek?ğŸ”½What kind of teachings should they rely on?

How should they give rise to the mind so that the multitude of the blind do not fall into wrong views?
Having said this, he prostrated with his whole body on the ground, making this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to Bodhisattva Universal Awakening:
Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Good man!
You are now able to ask the TathÄgata about such practice, and to bestow the fearless Dharma eye upon all sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age, enabling them to attain the holy path.
Listen attentively now!
I will explain it for you.
At that time, Bodhisattva Universal Awakening respectfully accepted the teaching with joy, and the great assembly listened in silence.
Good man!
Sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age who wish to generate the great resolve, seek good and virtuous friends, and practice the Way, should seek out those who possess right knowledge and insight.

Their minds do not dwell on appearances, are not attached to the realms of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and although they manifest worldly affairs, their minds are always pure. They may show various faults but praise pure conduct, not causing sentient beings to enter into unruliness.
Seeking such a person, one will attain accomplishment in unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
In the degenerate age, sentient beings who see such a person should make offerings to them, not sparing their own lives.

The good and virtuous friends always manifest purity in the four modes of deportment, and even if they manifest various faults, their minds are without arrogance, let alone grasping at wealth, wives, children, and relatives.

If a good man or woman does not give rise to evil thoughts towards those good and virtuous friends, they will be able to ultimately accomplish perfect enlightenment, and the mind-flower will blossom, illuminating the lands of the ten directions.
Good sons!
The wondrous Dharma realized by those good and virtuous friends should be free from the four illnesses.
What are the four illnesses?
First, the illness of fabrication. If there are people who say:
'I will create various practices in my original mind in order to seek perfect enlightenment.'
Because the nature of perfect enlightenment cannot be attained through fabrication, it is called an illness.
Second, the illness of indulgence. If there are people who say:

'We now neither cut off birth and death nor seek nirvana. Nirvana and birth and death are without the thought of arising or ceasing. We leave it to all things and follow the nature of phenomena, wishing to seek perfect enlightenment.'
Because the nature of perfect enlightenment is not to be left to exist, it is called an illness.
Third, the illness of cessation. If there are people who say like this:
'I now permanently cease all thoughts in my own mind and attain all natures, tranquil and equal. I wish to seek perfect enlightenment.'
Because the nature of perfect enlightenment is not to be united with cessation, it is called an illness.
Fourth, the illness of extinction. If there are people who say like this:

'I now permanently cut off all afflictions. Body and mind are ultimately empty and nonexistent, let alone the false realms of the sense faculties and sense objects. All are eternally tranquil. I wish to seek perfect enlightenment.'
Because the nature of perfect enlightenment is not a characteristic of tranquility, it is called an illness.
Those who are free from the four illnesses will know purity. One who contemplates in this way is called correct contemplation. If one contemplates otherwise, it is called deviant contemplation.
Good man!

Sentient beings in the degenerate age who wish to practice should serve a good friend and attend to a good teacher to the end of their lives. If that good teacher wishes to come near, they should eliminate arrogance. If they are far away, they should eliminate anger and resentment.

Perceiving adverse and favorable conditions as if they were empty space, they should understand that body and mind are ultimately equal, and that they share the same essence as all sentient beings without distinction. Practicing in this way, one may enter perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
Sentient beings in the degenerate age who do not attain enlightenment do so because of the seeds of self and other, hatred and love, from beginningless time. Therefore, they are not liberated.
If there are people who contemplate their enemies as if they were their parents, with no difference in their minds, they will immediately eliminate all illnesses.
In all dharmas, self and other, hatred and love, are also like this.
Good man!
Sentient beings in the degenerate age who wish to seek perfect enlightenment should give rise to the mind and speak in this way:

'I will cause all sentient beings throughout space to enter ultimate perfect enlightenment. Within perfect enlightenment, there is no one who attains enlightenment. Except for self, others, and all characteristics.'
If one gives rise to the mind in this way, one will not fall into wrong views.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Universal Awakening, you should know that in the degenerate age, all sentient beings
Who wish to seek good and wise advisors should seek right views,
With a mind far removed from the two vehicles.
Within the Dharma, eliminate the four illnesses, namely creation, cessation, acquiescence, and annihilation;
Be intimate without arrogance, and be distant without resentment.ğŸ”½When seeing various realms, one should give rise to a sense of wonder,
As if a Buddha has appeared in the world.
Do not violate the precepts, and the roots of precepts will be eternally pure,
Liberate all sentient beings, ultimately entering perfect enlightenment.
Without the characteristics of self, other, or person, always relying on wisdom,
One can transcend wrong views, realize enlightenment, and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.

Then Bodhisattva Perfect Enlightenment rose from his seat in the great assembly, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:

You have extensively explained for us the various skillful means of pure enlightenment, enabling sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age to greatly increase their benefits.

Having said this, he prostrated with his whole body on the ground, and made this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to Bodhisattva Perfect Enlightenment:

I will explain it for you.
At that time, Bodhisattva Perfect Enlightenment respectfully accepted the teaching with joy, and the great assembly listened in silence.

If Buddhas are present in the world, or after the Buddha's extinction, or in the Dharma-ending age, there are sentient beings with the Mahayana nature who have faith in the Buddha's secret great perfect enlightenment mind and wish to practice. If they are in a monastery or dwelling with a group of people, due to circumstances they should contemplate according to their abilities, as I have already explained;

If there are no other matters or conditions, then establish an altar and set a deadline. If setting a long deadline, it is 120 days, a medium deadline is 100 days, and a short deadline is 80 days. Dwell in a pure abode.
If the Buddha is present, then contemplate correctly;
If the Buddha has passed away, set up an image, keep the mind focused, and give rise to right mindfulness, which is the same as the Buddha's constant presence.
Hang various banners and flowers for three weeks. Bow to the names of the Buddhas in the ten directions, seek forgiveness and repent;
Encountering good circumstances, attain lightness and peace of mind.
After three weeks, focus the mind one-pointedly.
If you are spending the three months of summer retreat, you should dwell in pure bodhisattva quarters, with a mind free from Å›rÄvakas and without relying on a group of followers.
On the day of entering the retreat, in front of the Buddha, say thus:

'We, the bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs, riding the bodhisattva vehicle and cultivating the practice of quiescence, enter together the pure, true, and equal abode, taking the great perfect enlightenment as our monastery. Our body and mind dwell in the wisdom of equality, and nirvÄá¹‡a is our intrinsic nature, because we are not subject to any external authority.

Now we respectfully request not to rely on the Å›rÄvakas, but to dwell together with the tathÄgatas of the ten directions and the great bodhisattvas for three months, in order to cultivate the great causes and conditions for the unsurpassed, wondrous enlightenment of the bodhisattvas, and not to be bound by a retinue.'
Good sons!
This is called the bodhisattvas' demonstration of the summer retreat. After the three periods of time have passed, they may go wherever there is no obstruction.
Good sons!

If those sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age who cultivate the bodhisattva path and enter the three periods of time, they should not take as their object of hearing any of the phenomena that appear to them.
Good sons!
If sentient beings cultivate Å›amatha, they should first attain stillness and not give rise to thoughts. When stillness is extreme, then there is awareness.
In this way, the initial stillness extends from one's own body to the entire world, and the awakening is also like this.
Good man!
If one's awakening pervades an entire world, one can know all the thoughts that arise in a single sentient being within that world, and it is the same for a hundred thousand worlds;
one should not grasp at any object that is not heard.
Good man!

If sentient beings cultivate samÄdhi, they should first contemplate the TathÄgatas of the ten directions and all bodhisattvas in the worlds of the ten directions, gradually practicing diligently according to various methods, widely making great vows to cultivate their own seeds;
one should not grasp at any object that is not heard.
Good man!

If sentient beings cultivate dhyÄna, they first take up the method of counting. Clearly knowing the arising, abiding, and ceasing thoughts in the mind, distinguishing the number, in this way pervading the four modes of deportment, distinguishing the number of thoughts without not knowing, gradually progressing until knowing the number of raindrops in a hundred thousand worlds, just like seeing objects of use with the eyes;
The realms heard by them should never be grasped.
This is called the initial skillful means of the three contemplations.
If sentient beings universally cultivate the three kinds and diligently practice with vigor, they are called the TathÄgata appearing in the world;

If in the latter age, sentient beings with dull faculties wish to seek the Way but are unable to accomplish it due to karmic hindrances from the past, they should diligently repent and always arouse aspiration. First cutting off hatred, love, jealousy, flattery, and seeking a superior mind, practicing one of the three pure contemplations, if this contemplation is not attained, then practicing the other contemplations, the mind not letting go, gradually seeking realization.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Perfect Enlightenment, you should know that all sentient beings,
if they wish to seek the unsurpassed path, should first establish three periods of time,
repenting of karma from beginningless time.
Then, with right thought, not the realm of what is heard,
in the end, it cannot be grasped.
In samÄdhi, correctly upholding, in dhyÄna, the clear method of counting,
this is called the three pure contemplations.
If one can diligently cultivate, this is called the Buddha appearing in the world.
Always diligently repent of all sins from beginningless time,
if the obstructions are extinguished, the Buddha's realm will immediately manifest.

Then, the Bodhisattva Chief of Goodness in the great assembly immediately rose from his seat, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
Greatly compassionate World-Honored One!
Please extensively open and enlighten us and sentient beings of the degenerate age to such inconceivable matters.
World-Honored One!
What is the name of this Mahayana teaching?
How should we uphold it?
What merits will sentient beings attain by cultivating it?
How can we protect those who uphold the sÅ«tra?
To what lands will this teaching spread?
Having said this, he prostrated fully on the ground, making this request three times in succession.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the Bodhisattva Chief in Goodness:
Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Good man!
You are now able to ask the TathÄgata about the merits and names of the sÅ«tras and teachings for the sake of the bodhisattvas and sentient beings of the degenerate age.
Listen attentively now!
I will explain it for you.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Chief in Goodness respectfully accepted the teaching with joy, and the great assembly listened in silence.
Good man!

This sÅ«tra is spoken by hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of Ganges' sands of Buddhas, guarded by the TathÄgatas of the three times, taken refuge in by the Bodhisattvas of the ten directions, the pure eyes of the twelve divisions of the canon, this sÅ«tra is named the MahÄvaipulya DhÄraá¹‡Ä« of Perfect Enlightenment, it is also named the SÅ«tra of Definitive Meaning, it is also named the King of Secret SamÄdhis, it is also named the TathÄgata's Definitive Realm, it is also named the TathÄgata's Treasury of Self-nature Distinctions, you should uphold it.

This sÅ«tra only reveals the TathÄgata's realm, only the Buddha TathÄgata can fully proclaim it;
If the Bodhisattvas and sentient beings of the degenerate age rely on this practice, gradually progressing to the Buddha's stage.

This sÅ«tra is named the Sudden Teaching MahÄyÄna, the sudden-enlightenment sentient beings are awakened from this, it also includes all the gradual practitioners.
It is like the great ocean not refusing small streams, even mosquitoes and asuras who drink its water all get to be satisfied.
Good man!

If someone were to fill the trichiliocosm with the seven precious substances and use it as an offering, it would not be as good as someone hearing the name of this sutra and its meaning in a single verse.
Good man!

If someone were to teach sentient beings as numerous as the sands of a hundred Ganges rivers to attain the fruit of arhatship, it would not be as good as someone expounding this sutra and discerning half a verse.
Good man!

If there are people who hear the name of this sutra and their faith is not confused, know that this person has not planted various merits and wisdom with one or two buddhas, but like this, up to the end of the Ganges sands, in all buddhas' places they have planted various good roots and heard this sutra's teachings.
You, good men!
You should protect those who practice in the end times, do not let evil demons and various non-Buddhists disturb their bodies and minds and cause them to give rise to retrogression.

At that time, in the assembly, there were 80,000 vajra-wielding deities such as HuÅ›Ä« VajrapÄá¹‡i, VajrapÄá¹‡i, and NÄ«lamba VajrapÄá¹‡i, together with their retinues. They immediately rose from their seats, bowed their heads at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
If in the future Dharma-ending age, there are sentient beings who can uphold this definitive Great Vehicle, we will protect them as we would guard our own eyes;
up to the place where one practices for the site of enlightenment, we vajra-wielding deities will personally lead our followers to guard day and night, causing them not to regress.
Their families will forever be free from calamities and hindrances, epidemics will be eliminated, and they will have abundant wealth and never lack anything.

At that time, the Great Brahma Heaven King, the twenty-eight heaven kings, the King of Mount Sumeru, the Heaven King who Protects the Country, and others rose from their seats, bowed their heads at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, and said to the Buddha:

World-Honored One!

I will also protect and guard those who uphold this sÅ«tra, attending to them morning and evening, not allowing them to regress. If there are ghosts and spirits within a yojana of where they reside who encroach upon their domain, I will cause them to be shattered into tiny particles.

After the Buddha had spoken this sÅ«tra, all the bodhisattvas, devas, dragons, ghosts, spirits, the eight groups of beings and their retinues, as well as the various celestial kings, Brahma kings, and all the great assembly, upon hearing what the Buddha had said, greatly rejoiced, and with faith and understanding they received and upheld it.
